s.text: "Today's Papers" can only guess they are shoes so expensive that most folks can only look at them in the store window, or on their lawyers.
The NYT says the success of the anti-bilingualism measure will pave the way for similar "assaults" on other such programs around the country.
As a result, billions of dollars of goods customarily sit for hours at the three borders involved, a particular disaster in today's just-in-time inventory economy.
Everybody looks down on lawyers who pay to advertise in the back of the paper.
The case, says the paper, could result in the largest fine in EPA history.
The goal, apparently, is to be the kind of lawyer paid to be advertised in the front of the paper.
